security: Sharing the details of attempts to recruit Soviet officials could expose methods used to identify and approach potential assets, and could also damage relations with the Soviet Union. The document mentions: 'the recruitment attempt and personal harrassment of Soviet official ABCDET (201-733422)'.
summary: A report details the involvement of Subject LIHUFF-1 in the recruitment attempt and personal harassment of a Soviet official (ABCDET) in June 1968, as narrated by Keith Cameron Johnson, Dean of Men at the University of the Americas.
summary_one_paragraph: The report describes Subject LIHUFF-1's involvement in the recruitment and harassment of Soviet official ABCDET, based on a narrative provided by Keith Cameron Johnson, Dean of Men at the University of the Americas. Johnson, who rented his house from LIHUFF-1, recounted an incident where he observed suspicious individuals around his property, possibly connected to the Soviet official's case. This involved strange men appearing at Johnson's house, attempted break-ins, and interactions with local law enforcement, which led Johnson to believe he was under surveillance, all potentially exposing the Station's connection to LIHUFF-1 if the Soviets suspected any link.
title: LIHUFF-1: Involvement in Recruitment Attempt and Personal Harrassment of Soviet Official ABCDET
